data.sampled:
Increase. You can benefit from a decrease in the stock price by buying the call option and selling the long stock position while holding the difference. As an example of how to proceed:

1. Long one call option: Sell to buy one call option and the Stock position, for a $26.5 benefit 
2. Sell your long position of $200 
3. Buy back into the trade for $260 
4. Long one call: Buy to sell one call option and the Stock position for $13.5 profit 
5. Buy back into the trade for $280
6. Total profit $26.5.

Decrease will only occur if the stock price drops.

prompt.content: You are a derivatives investor.

Assume all contracts are for 100 shares. Answer with no explanation, only a classification. Given the expiration dates are the same, what is the name of the option strategy being implemented in the following? Sell 1 $205 strike price call at $5.00. Buy 1 $210 strike price call at $1.50.

data.sampled: The option strategy being implemented in the given options trade is called a Bull Call Spread. It consists of selling two at-the-money options (one bull call and one put) with the same expiration date and the same strike price, while buying one more at-the-money option (a put) with a lower strike price and the same expiration date. This strategy aims to profit from the decline in the price of the underlying asset while limiting the risk by using the puts as protection.

prompt.content: You are a derivatives investor.

Assume all contracts are for 100 shares. Answer with no explanation, only a classification. Given the expiration dates are the same, what is the name of the option strategy being implemented in the following? Sell 1 $265 strike price call at $17.75. Buy 1 $280 strike price call at $7.40.

data.sampled: The option strategy being implemented is "Buying-Call-Selling-Strategy" also known as the B-C-S strategy. This strategy consists in buying a call option to purchase an asset at a lower price and selling a call option to buy the same asset at a higher price. The upside potential from this strategy is limited as the risk of the underlying asset falling in value is also limited.
